conclusion: Need to find the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced emf when the wire frame rotates through an angle of 60°.
The induced emf in a rotating loop is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = B S \omega \sin(\omega t) \).
The instantaneous emf when the loop has rotated 60° is: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{instantaneous}} = B S \omega \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \).
The instantaneous current \( I \) is given by Ohm's law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} \).
The instantaneous current when the loop has rotated 60° is: \( I_{\text{instantaneous}} = \frac{\sqrt{3} B S \omega}{2R} \).
The average emf over a time interval is given by the change in magnetic flux divided by the time interval.
The magnetic flux \( \Phi \) through the loop is: \( \Phi = B S \cos(\omega t) \).
The change in flux from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = \frac{\pi/3}{\omega} \) is: \( \Delta \Phi = B S \left(\frac{1}{2} - 1\right) = -\frac{1}{2} B S \).
The time taken to rotate 60° is: \( \Delta t = \frac{\pi}{3\omega} \).
The average emf is: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{average}} = \frac{-\frac{1}{2} B S}{\frac{\pi}{3\omega}} = -\frac{3 B S \omega}{2\pi} \).
Since emf is typically considered as a magnitude in such contexts: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{average}} = \frac{3 B S \omega}{2\pi} \).
Final Answers: Instantaneous induced current: \( I = \frac{\sqrt{3} B S \omega}{2R} \), Average induced emf: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{average}} = \frac{3 B S \omega}{2\pi} \).
